text:
Ronie Shilo: I would like
to introduce our three speakers today. So Nicolas Sauvage is
the founder and president

of TDK Ventures, which
is the corporate VC arm of TDK corporation.

A Japan headquartered
electronics manufacturer. TDK ventures invests
globally in seed

to be round startups that
leverage fundamental material science to unlock an attractive
and sustainable future

of the world. Nicola is an alumnus of ISEN,
the London Business School,
INSEAD and the Stanford GSB. So lots of different experience.

And Nicola, welcome and thank
you for joining us today. NICOLAS SAUVAGE: Thank you. Ronie Shilo: Aparna
Subramanian is director

of engineering at Shopify. She has 17 plus
years of experience as a technology leader
building engineering teams.

She has successfully
built and launched several products across
multicloud and machine learning

platforms. She's passionate about creating
and developing inclusive teams where people feel they belong.

She holds a master's degree in
computer science from Boston University and a
bachelor's in engineering

from Anna University in India. And she's based in the
San Francisco Bay Area.

Thank you for joining
us Aparna and welcome. And then finally, Deborah Kelly
is an Economics and Statistics

professor at the
University of San Diego. She's also involved with
the University's Leadership

Certificate Program. She's been chair of
multiple committees and has led a variety
of strategic efforts

within the university. And previously in her career
was a bank branch manager

and a software engineer. Deborah welcome and thank
you for joining us today.

So we're going to spend the
next 45 minutes or 40 minutes

together. And what we wanted
to spend our webinar today is learn a little
bit about your experience

as managers navigating this
very complicated transition that we've all experienced
over the last two years from--

most of you, I'm assuming, were
fully in person in the office, then likely transitioned
to fully remote

as the pandemic hit us. And then are probably
at different places right now within
your organizations

as we start to transition back. So what I wanted to do is
start by asking each of you

to tell us just a little
bit about the team you lead or the organization
that you are a part of,

and where that team
and organization is in that journey from
in-person to remote and back.

So Aparna, why don't
we start with you? APARNA SUBRAMANIAN:
Yeah, sounds good. I'm a Director of
Engineering at Shopify,

and Shopify is a software
as a service cloud platform for e-commerce.

We support millions of merchants
across 175 different countries. And my organization decided
to go fully digital by design,
which is remote first culture. So all of us are remote.

We are going to be
remote all the time, and that's a decision
that we've made so that we can level the
playing field for everybody.

And we also see this
as an opportunity to future proof Shopify.

And in terms of where we
are with that journey,

I think it's-- personally, it has
worked out really well for me and my teams.

So we are no longer restricted
to hiring the best talent just in North America. We are able to hire the best
talent across the world.

So that's been great. And speaking from my
own personal experience as a mother of two
young kids, I really

love the flexibility
of being able to design my work around my life.

And when I talk to people in
my team and other friends, they really appreciate
the flexibility

and being more available
to their family and kids. And certainly, not
looking forward

to go back to having to
design our lives around work.

Ronie Shilo: Wonderful. Thank you very much. Deborah, why don't you
tell us a little bit

about where you are from
and where your university is currently on that journey?

DEBORAH KELLY: Well, just
as everybody university, they went remote.

And the thing is I had
actually taken some time off to attend a business
analytics program, which was--

this was before the pandemic. And I was-- we
had online classes

and then we got together on
campus a couple of times. Well, I thought it was
an amazing experience.

We got to know each
other really well for one thing each of the
classes required us to have peer
learning sessions before

and review our homework
before we went to class. So when we got in person,
I was like, oh, hi.

Hi, yeah, I get to
see you in person now. But I knew, we knew each other.

And so when everybody
was shutting down, they're complaining
and it's like, hey, I've been on Zoom,
that's a great experience.

So it was interesting seeing
how people were adapting and having problems with it
when I had a great experience,

but then I do see that it is-- I wasn't being forced
to do it all of a sudden

just like businesses
and universities were having to do that.

And I do see a lot of-- I saw a lot of leaders that
didn't have the leadership

skills that they needed
to be in person or online

to be able to lead
a group of people when I know students
didn't like being at home.

But you need to set up some
of the guidelines for having

videos on and people
to be paying attention. And then also some social
time so that people

would get to know each other. So it's been a really
interesting experience to-- based on my experiences
how people are handling it.

Ronie Shilo: Absolutely. And so we've kind of--
well, in a few minutes get into some of the best
practices or some of the things

that you have tried across
your teams or organizations, but it sounds like a
Aparna's organization,

Shopify has made the
decision to remain remote. And there are many,
many organizations

or quite a few of that have
made similar decisions. Deborah, it sounds like
in higher education,

I think that is the case that
Stanford as well, by the way, certainly, there is a push to
start to come back onto campus

and be residential to
the extent possible. But there are some universities
who have also decided

to remain more fully virtual. Nicolas, what about TDK
Ventures, what have you

done in this kind of question
of starting to come back and handling that transition.

NICOLAS SAUVAGE: Well, so TDK
Ventures is a corporate VC. And venture capital is all about
people, about entrepreneurs,

about partners. And it's very much a
white-glove type of services.

And so we've been looking
at growing our team. And we moved from five
people before the pandemic

to now 15 people. And we are trying to be
close to the entrepreneurs, close to the
innovation ecosystem.

So clearly in the US, we have
Silicon Valley and Boston

on the east. But we also have Japan,
France, soon India.

And it's interesting,
because apart from two times where we managed to get everyone
together, 2/3 of the team

was recruited remotely. We didn't get a chance to
meet them face to face.

So that was also
a learning here. What's interesting
about my journey is that 10 years
ago, I was in Taiwan.

I was working from home. I was traveling a lot, but five
years I was working from home.

So I have some appreciation
of the benefits of working from home
but also the value of being close to customers,
close to your colleagues.

And so maybe I will end by
saying that our first two investments, which
was before pandemic,

we actually did
everything on Zoom. So it was actually
already remote. And I feel like we managed
to get into a setup

where we had all the processes
and the tools already ready for us to be remote.
Ronie Shilo: That's great.

Yeah, and I think
kind of both you and Deborah
mentioned that having some exposure to Zoom
and to virtual tools

before the pandemic was
really useful in terms of being able to make that
transition more quickly,

and to be able to still feel
confident and less disoriented

as this was happening. What are some things that
were surprising to you

as you transitioned to
Zoom in terms of things that you saw-- or not to
Zoom, to try transition

to a remote environment--
in terms of some things that you saw with your
teams, with your staff,

and that you learned about your
team as part of this process?

Aparna, would you like to start? APARNA SUBRAMANIAN: Yeah. Yeah, happy to. Yeah. So the one thing that
was really interesting

for me was as we decided to hire
more and onboard more people,

I think onboarding was a
very interesting aspect. As much as we wanted people to
work asynchronously and rely

on documentation, which
is which works really well for a lot of everyday
interaction meetings,

decision making, but
handing somebody plenty of documentation and asking them
to onboard themselves and ramp

up doesn't quite work very well. So onboarding is one
area that has been--

which I personally find
that it really benefits from a high touch interaction.

Like Nicolas said, like
working with entrepreneurs, working with customers,
I think onboarding

is one such area in my opinion. And having an onboarding
buddy who is in a time zone

that's closest to the person
who's joining the team, and having that face-to-face
interaction of--

in a video call, of course-- where they can virtually
use a whiteboard,

ask a lot of
open-ended questions, and just be available
for them and to develop that sense of
belonging to the team,

I think that really
goes a long way. So I think that's
one area that I would say not to
rely too much on

this asynchronous communication
and documentation.

Ronie Shilo: Wonderful-- NICOLAS SAUVAGE: I can
share about onboarding-- oh. Ronie Shilo: Yeah, go ahead. NICOLAS SAUVAGE: We have
this system at TDK Ventures,

where we want to do a bit
like Airbnb, where they had this challenging
team mindset of,

how do we get the onboarding
from a four-star experience to a five stars to six
stars to seven stars?

And we are getting to
a point where now we have one person who's
actually onboarding

two weeks in advance. And it's not too much, but
it's just about saying, oh, we can't wait to see you.

We are planning
all these meetings. This is a type of
presentation you might want to read at your
leisure if you want in advance.

We are planning calls for you
with various team members, maybe three per day
on your first week.

And we are really
challenging ourselves, how do we make it
seven-star onboarding? And this is even more
important when it's remote,

because people don't have the
chance to get into the office, shake hands with everyone,
and see everyone, and then

go for lunch together. So you really need to go
and be more inclusive.

Actually, I like
what Aparna defined in her introduction, which
is inclusive team where

they feel like they belong. And where-- the
"belong," I think, is a very important word. And getting this
seven-star onboarding

is a way of fitting
in the team even though you're not going to
meet face to face right away. Ronie Shilo: Mm-hmm.

DEBORAH KELLY: Actually,
that's the case with-- even with students. I talked to a
student the other day that said her first
year of being involved--

being on as part of a
university, she was in India. And she didn't know anyone.

And then now she's
come to campus, but then like, the other day
with spring break, everybody

disappeared. And she said, ah,
I don't know who-- she doesn't know
who to connect to.

And so I think that's
really important is, when they are-- when you're
bringing somebody in,

hey, get them connected somehow. Make sure that they
know some other people. So important.

Ronie Shilo: And
Aparna, you spoke about kind of data
sharing and information

sharing, both synchronously
and asynchronously. Are there any-- and I think
you connected that to hiring,

but maybe that's
true, also, across. One of the questions that we
saw that came in through the Q&A

is a question about
the fact that companies might be losing some-- or
organizations might be losing

some benefits of kind
of shared knowledge and information with this move
to virtual and fully remote.

Have any of you
experienced that? And if so, how are some--
what are some ways that you

yourselves as leaders or
employees have tackled that, or maybe from--

in a more systemic way
that your organization has addressed data sharing
and information sharing?

APARNA SUBRAMANIAN: Yeah. I think it's really important
to invest in tooling, content

management systems,
or whatever homegrown systems or commercial
software that people can buy,

so that there is complete
visibility of information. And that's only part of
the solution in my opinion,

because there is
still definitely tremendous value in having
interactions virtually,

or social interactions,
or once in a while, getting people
together physically,

and things like that. So I think it really
is a combination. And things that help--
have helped me personally

is having show-and-tells
where people come and share their work, maybe create videos
or actually come and present

live about the work
that they've done, some project decisions that
have happened over the time,

and stuff like that. So it's like asynchronous
and documentation alone is not the solution.

It really has to be complemented
with in-person interaction, social interaction, virtual
meetings, show-and-tells.

And one other tool that's
really helpful is video message. Sometimes I just
create video messages

that can be shared with
my team and organization, because it just communicates
a lot more than the content

and what's written. So that's another
tool that is useful.

Ronie Shilo: Nicolas
would you like to share? NICOLAS SAUVAGE: And I saw
a question also in the Q&A

from Deb Corrigan about
tools and modification to the processes. I don't think we
changed our processes.

And I think we use
the same tools. But what we try to do is
to share the processes

more clearly. So all our processes start
with being entrepreneurs first.

And so we always start
from the entrepreneurs and what we can deliver to them. And so everything we do
is along that perspective.

And what that means
is actually, we had already the right
processes, we just had to make sure that everyone
knew them and what to expect,

which was good-- So one thing that I spent
a lot of time on, actually, was refine and communicate
very clearly roles

and responsibilities in
everyone in the team. And so that,
actually, is probably

what was most important, because
when you can meet face to face, you can very quickly agree
who's doing what and why.

But once you're remote, and
you can't talk to everyone at the same time,
I think much more

clarity about who
is in charge of what and who should be
included for information

or for decisions, that, I
think, mattered much more. And that, also, I think removed
some of the stress, which--

I mean, the stress increased
for everyone moving to remote, and all your bearings are gone.

And so to have more
clarity about roles and responsibilities, I felt
like, was a good step forward.

Ronie Shilo: And so
that really sounds like, again, a focus on
sharing of information

in different ways. So even if the
processes existed, there is a heightened need to
be very transparent about them,

make sure that they're shared,
make sure that they're clear, that the roles and
responsibilities are clear.

There is less opportunity to
rely on kind of information

and data sharing that
just happens spontaneously and organically. But really as managers, you
want to be a lot more thoughtful

about how that is shared. And also, Aparna,
I heard you say,

which medium we choose
to share information. Sometimes it's text,
sometimes it's video,

sometimes it's asynchronous,
sometimes it is synchronous. So being a lot more
thoughtful about that.

So a related question
I had is, I mean, I think something that comes
up a lot as people discuss

remote work is, how
do you maintain kind of the social connectivity?

And again, that's
something that I think managers have to be
a lot more thoughtful about and can't just
rely on a coffee--

a conversation next to the water
cooler or the coffee machine. And so can you share a
little bit about some things

that you've tried
and have worked, or that have not worked,
as you were figuring out

some ways to promote
this social interaction? APARNA SUBRAMANIAN: Yeah, I
can try to answer that first.

So I think it's really important
to have a process budget

around these team events. I think it really
goes a long way when

the HR department or
leadership sets aside a certain budget per quarter
per team, per year per team,

and have resources. That may be external vendors
or online virtual team building

activities that people can-- managers or leaders can
sign their team up for.

I think those things
definitely go a long way. And to your earlier point, it's
like leveraging all of this,

but also just being
very intentional about the culture and the team. So I think as
managers, one thing--

as a manager, one
thing I've learned is to really step back and
let my team own the decisions.

And I can get some of
that time back to really be intentional about
the culture that I want to build in the
team, to really be

intentional about the
social interactions and the opportunities that I
can create for them to build

that relationships, instead of
being the bottleneck in making
decisions for my teams.

NICOLAS SAUVAGE:
One thing I did-- DEBORAH KELLY: One thing-- go ahead. NICOLAS SAUVAGE: No, no. Please go ahead.

DEBORAH KELLY: OK. Well, actually I just
want to play off one thing that she just said is, I think
one thing is when you come

to these meetings,
to get others to talk and not just you
being the leader.

Because then it's just like, OK,
yeah, just yammer, on whatever.

But if you're, OK, could you
say something about this, or ask some questions
to get others involved,

and that also gets you to
learn about those other people, what they're doing. And that really can be helpful.

Sometimes with
introverts, you need to tell them in advance you're
going to call them on them so that they can maybe prepare.

But also, just trying to get
more people in the discussion,

not to make the
meeting any longer, but just to make sure that
we hear from others and not

just the manager. Go ahead, Nicolas. NICOLAS SAUVAGE: Thank you. I think one thing I
was very conscious

is that there is a lot
of temptation to add new things, to do new stuff. And I was conscious
that this could actually

add even more stress, not
reduce stress or improve social connectivity.

And that's why I went for this
training, because I wanted to hear about best
practices from the teachers

but also from the
practitioners, everyone trying to figure out how to do things.

And I wanted to be very
conscious about not adding new stuff that
could be counterproductive.

And I agree with also Aparna
about the intentional. And so one of the
things that I did--

and it comes from my own
management perspective, which is, what it is that you wake up
in the morning excited to do.

And one of my team members,
my executive assistant, she loves people.

She really wants
people to feel good. And so I asked Eva to really
spend time thinking about who

to connect during the week and
during the day, and make sure they are okay. And to have one person whose
role is actually to make sure

that everyone is OK and
no one is burning out, no one is stressed, and maybe to
figure out what to do with it,

and maybe potentially
escalate to me, or maybe find a solution
without me in the loop, that,

I thought, was a
good way to make sure that we had this connective
tissue in the team that

was still happening even
though we were all remote. That's one thing that I
think worked really well,

is to have that one person
waking up in the morning and thinking, how do we make
sure the team, and each team

member, feel good,
and can speak up.

Ronie Shilo: Yeah. So what I love about
that is, basically you're sharing two things.

One is, you're playing
off of people's strengths and natural kind of
competencies so that it's not

an additional chore but is
something that they really like. And I think a part that you kind
of mentioned something similar.

And the other is, I think
it ties into your earlier point, where you said you
want-- you clearly defined

roles and responsibilities. So you told your staff
member, this is your role,

this is part of your
job is to be checking in with these people and
reporting back to me

or looking out for the team
so nobody's burning out, which I think is great, so
creating that kind of clarity

so that people know what is-- that this is expected of
them, and that this is just as

important a job
as, maybe, I don't know, doing some other
type of project, because--

NICOLAS SAUVAGE: And to-- Ronie Shilo: Go ahead. NICOLAS SAUVAGE: And to
Aparna's point about budgets, she has a budget, where
she can go and have

one-to-one lunch with them. She can send flowers. She can do a few things that
are personal touches that

makes you belong. And that's why I really
like the word to "belong," because for me, if you
talk about inclusion,

it's about feeling
like you can belong, you can speak your mind,
and people will listen.

APARNA SUBRAMANIAN: Yeah. And I also love the ritual. I think if we have a
ritual around like,

OK, this is how our team
is going to get together, maybe every quarter we're
going to meet for lunch

or have a virtual coffee
or something like that, then it creates that routine
and something for people

to look forward to. Maybe I have other
personal responsibilities, I'm not able to join right now.

But maybe I'll be able
to join in summer. And I can then plan to be
able to travel or be there

the next time we meet as a team. So I think there's
really something about that having that ritual.

And for example, when I
have my staff meetings-- I mean, of course, for
all the virtual meetings

we want to have an agenda, and
we want to really be prepared, and all of that. All of those are
really best practices.

But then what I've
found is, once in a while to have a staff
meeting, with my direct team,

that has no agenda, and
just show up in the meeting and ask, how was your week?

Like, what was the
highlight or lowlight of your week in this past week?

And I've noticed
that people open up. And people really like to
not have structure sometimes,

or have an agenda-packed
meeting where we're just discussing topics
or status or things like that.

So I think one thing
is to also be-- understand what works
for your team and mix

things up as needed.  Ronie Shilo: That's great. So I have a question that
came-- a few questions

along similar lines. They have to do
with the work hours

and burnout-related questions
and focus, I would say. So let me explain
what the question is.

So there is a question
that came in around, how do you figure out--
if you defined clear work

hours during the
day to make sure that people don't work excessive
amount of time and burnout,

or have you left
this more free form? And a related note--
is there-- have

you found ways to address
either multitasking, where employees are
supposedly in a meeting

but actually, they're
doing something else, or that they're just
burning out because

of the excessive
amount of meetings, or time on camera, et cetera? So this is a pretty
broad question tying

in a few different things. But feel free to respond
from whichever perspective

you feel you have the
most to say about. So Deborah, do you
want to go first?

DEBORAH KELLY: I'm going to let
one of the other ones go first, and then I'll play into it. Ronie Shilo: OK, sounds good.

APARNA SUBRAMANIAN: Yeah. So I think it's
really important not to make everybody work in the
time zone of the headquarters.

I mean, I think we have to get
used to this model where people are working during their
preferred daytime working hours

in their time zone. And I understand the need for
some synchronous communication

and some overlap,
but I think we just have to figure out a way
to make it two or three

hours of overlap, or
whatever the minimum overlap needed for teams to
communicate across time zones.

Because this is just
one of those long-term, unsustainable things to do,
is to have a certain team

work in a completely
different time zone. And I think as leaders,
it's very important to model that and
enforce that right,

and to create opportunities
such that an extended amount

of overlap is not necessary. And when I say
"modeling behavior," like if leaders start attending
meetings in early morning

or answering emails after
work hours or in the weekends, it indirectly creates
that expectation

or that culture that, oh, OK,
maybe this is the work ethic, this demonstrates work ethic--

being able to extend
oneself and having to devote their
personal time, but which

is-- which really is not. I mean, I think it really
sets a bad example. And I think as leaders,
we have that opportunity

to set the culture for the
rest of their organization and the company. And they should certainly
model that behavior.

DEBORAH KELLY: Actually, that
plays into some of the things that I've heard. For one thing, the
research had to be--

in the first year
of the shutdown was the fact that people were
more productive that we're

working from home, but also
that they were answering-- they could get up,
maybe eat breakfast

and that kind of thing,
and kind of split their day instead of
normally, we drive to work,

and then at 5 o'clock we close
the computer and go home. But now some people
were, oh, OK, well,

it's kind of calm
here in the evening. I'll answer some emails. And they were answering
emails at 9 or 10 o'clock.

But the thing is, yes, worry
about burnout, that's for sure.

But also that it
does give people kind of the chance to spread it
out, spread out their workday,

kind of manage family
and everything else. And so that was working
out rather nicely.

NICOLAS SAUVAGE: I was going
to give an analogy for me about overworking and even
burnout risk, which I think

is-- if you see a group
of boys where you're taking a photo of a group of
boys-- it tends to be boys,

I think, one of them will
stand up to be a bit taller. And then another one
will try to do the same.

And very quickly, all
the boys try to stand up to be looking taller. And then everyone is at the
same height on the photo

as it would have been if
no one is standing up, but everyone is suffering from
trying to stand up taller.

And I feel like with everyone
moving remote and saving time on commute, you end up
with people working even harder.

And then at some point, you
actually can't even control it. You don't even realize
you're standing up taller for way too long.

And so I think overworking
and burnout risk is true, even in face to face,
even before the pandemic.

And it's very hard to identify. It's even harder to do remote. And I can speak for
myself, because we just

had last week our second face
to face for all the team. And I think there are
two of my team members,

I think, are
overworking to the point where they could
risk burning out. And one reports directly to
me, so I am taking steps.

But this is really, really
hard to identify when you just meet in Zoom, and the
person is smiling,

and you can't really tell. So I'm looking for
answers to this, actually.

But the way I'm looking
at it is this group of people who are
trying to stand taller, but actually it ends up being
everyone the same anyway.

Ronie Shilo: That's
a great analogy.

And I think some best
practices that I've seen

have to do with
really defining hours. So I think, Aparna,
you were talking about that a little bit.

I mean, one, in terms
of role modeling, but also in terms of,
these are kind of work time

that we are expecting the entire
team to participate in and then be much more flexible
about other times,

and try to disencourage,
really, people from working too long hours.

And I know, Nicolas, you
shared with a group of us earlier some of the
policies that you've

developed for coming
back to the office, which takes the same approach. Maybe you want to
say a couple of words

about that, where really,
you've defined some times that are in-person times,
and then some more flex

time around that. NICOLAS SAUVAGE: Yeah. And maybe I can first
say that last week,

we did inside
methodology review. And we identified
that in our team,

half people are extroverts,
and half people are introverts. And what's interesting
with that is

that you can expect the
extroverts wanting to be back in the office and to
have the interactions,

and the introverts
wanting it but maybe not to the same extent. And so the way
we've designed our--

we call it the "work
from the office" policy, where it's really a
"work from home" policy. It's just setting
the expectation

that we expect some time, which
is a Monday and Thursdays.

And we chose the time so it's
actually nice commute time, because it's when
everyone is commuting. So it's, I think,
11:00 AM to 4:00

PM, where everyone is
expected to be in the office to be building some
kind of camaraderie,

I think, as a kind of whiteboard
moment, where we can brainstorm and create together. But apart from that, as long
as a person has all the right

tools at home, which
sometimes they don't-- especially for interns, they
